title: 113_hr3463
content: The "Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013" may be cited as the Border Patrol Rate of Pay. The Border Patrol Rate of Pay aims to strengthen U.S. Customs and Border Protection, ensure agents are ready for necessary work, and have flexibility in scheduling for mission requirements. It also establishes rates of pay for Border Patrol agents. In this section, definitions include the term 'available to work' for Border Patrol agents accessible for unscheduled duty, 'Border Patrol agent' performing enforcement functions, and 'covered border patrol activities' for specific duties. The term 'covered border patrol activities' for a Border Patrol agent includes detecting and preventing illegal entry, arresting suspects, attending training, taking approved leave, traveling on orders, being on official time, and excused absence for relocation purposes. The term 'level 1 border patrol rate of pay' for a Border Patrol agent is defined as the rate equal to the rate of basic pay for level 1 of the Border Patrol. The term 'level 1 border patrol rate of pay' for a Border Patrol agent is 1.25 times the hourly rate of basic pay, 'level 2 border patrol rate of pay' is 1.125 times the hourly rate of basic pay, and a 'work period' is a 14-day biweekly pay period. Border Patrol agents must elect their pay rate annually. Border Patrol agents must annually elect their pay rate between level 1, level 2, or decline both rates. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will establish election procedures, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection will provide information 60 days before each year. U.S. Customs and Border Protection must provide Border Patrol agents with information on pay rate elections annually, 60 days before each year. Failure to elect will result in a default election. Congress recommends that no more than 10% of agents decline assignments. More than 10% of Border Patrol agents decline to be assigned to level 1 or level 2 border patrol pay rates. Level 1 pay rate includes 8 hours of regular time work per day and 2 additional hours of scheduled overtime, with pay at the level 1 border patrol rate. The Border Patrol agent shall receive pay at the level 1 border patrol rate of pay for regular and scheduled overtime work. They will not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off for scheduled overtime. Any hours available for work during a work period will be included in regular or scheduled overtime hours. Compensation will be in the form of compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate. The Border Patrol agent at level 2 will work 5 days a week, with 8 hours of regular time per day and 1 additional hour of scheduled overtime each day. The Border Patrol agent at level 2 will work 5 days a week, with 8 hours of regular time per day and 1 additional hour of scheduled overtime each day. For regular time work, the agent will receive pay at the level 2 border patrol rate. However, for scheduled overtime work, the agent will not receive additional compensation or compensatory time off. The Border Patrol agent shall receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay for hours of work in excess of 90 hours during a work period, as determined in accordance with section 5542(a)(7). The agent shall be charged leave in increments of 8 hours for 1 shift of leave, regardless of the length of the shift. The Border Patrol agent is scheduled to work 8 hours per day, 5 days a week, with any available work hours included in the regular schedule. They will receive compensatory time off or overtime pay for hours exceeding 80 hours during a work period. Eligibility for other premium pay is also granted to Border Patrol agents. Border Patrol agents are eligible for premium pay for night work, Sunday and holiday pay, and overtime pay as determined by specific sections. They are not eligible for other forms of premium pay except as provided. Pay received at certain levels is treated as basic pay. Border Patrol agents at certain pay levels receive basic pay for specific purposes outlined in the law. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection has the authority to require agents to work overtime as needed, including during emergencies. Border Patrol agents may receive overtime pay for hours worked in excess of 100 hours during a 14-day pay period, as per amendments to the United States Code. Border Patrol agents are eligible for overtime pay for hours worked in excess of 90 hours during a 14-day pay period if they have an election to be eligible for the level 2 border patrol rate of pay. Overtime work must be officially ordered or approved in advance, and compensatory time off is provided for any other overtime hours. Border Patrol agents receive overtime pay for hours worked in excess of 80 hours during a 14-day pay period if they have an election for the level 2 border patrol rate of pay. Overtime work must be officially ordered or approved in advance, and compensatory time off is provided for any other overtime hours. During a 14-day biweekly pay period, Border Patrol agents can receive overtime pay for hours exceeding 80, with compensatory time off for any additional overtime hours. There is a limit of 8 hours of compensatory time off for overtime work, but this limit can be waived by U.S. Customs and Border Protection as deemed necessary. U.S. Customs and Border Protection can waive the 8-hour compensatory time limit for Border Patrol agents for overtime work. There is a cap of 240 hours of compensatory time off per year, which must be used within 1 year of accrual. Amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 are also made. Amendments are made to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 regarding Border Patrol agents, allowing for a waiver of the 8-hour compensatory time limit for overtime work. The cap for compensatory time off is set at 240 hours per year, to be used within 1 year of accrual. Additionally, a new provision is added for any employee who is a Border Patrol agent as defined in section 5550(a) of title 5, United States Code. Amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 allow Border Patrol agents to waive the 8-hour compensatory time limit for overtime work, with a cap of 240 hours per year.
